docs.lead_paragraph: In the most pointed criticism yet of her opponent in the New York Senate race, Hillary Rodham Clinton attacked Representative Rick A. Lazio today for not supporting a federal bill that would allow patients to sue health maintenance organizations and accused him of waffling on other issues. ''I think you'll find when you look at my opponent's record, he has a pattern of changing positions, trying to figure out which way the political winds are blowing,'' Mrs. Clinton told reporters this morning at Northern Westchester Hospital Center, where she championed a so-called patients' bill of rights now before Congress.

headline.main: Mrs. Clinton Accuses Lazio of Waffling

docs.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton, in most pointed criticism yet of her opponent in New York Senate race, attacks Representative Rick A Lazio for not supporting federal bill that would allow patients to sue health maintenance organizations; accuses him of waffling on many of main issues; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it had contributed 60.5 million shares of G.M. Class H common stock, valued at about $5.6 billion, to employee benefit plans. The company transmitted 53.6 million shares to its United States hourly rate employees pension plan and 6.9 million shares to its welfare benefit trust, a voluntary employees' health-care and life insurance benefit trust. The contributions are part of the company's plan to restructure its economic interest in its Hughes Electronics unit, G.M.'s wholly owned subsidiary that makes satellite TV systems. The move will reduce G.M.'s annual pension and retirement benefit expenses and improve operating earnings.

headline.main: G.M. PLACES $5.6 BILLION OF STOCK IN EMPLOYEE PLANS

docs.lead_paragraph: After insisting for months that private insurance was the only way to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly, House Republicans announced today that the federal government must be ''the insurer of last resort,'' to guarantee that drug coverage was available to all Medicare beneficiaries. The Republicans said they had nearly finished drafting a bill under which the government would offer subsidies to private insurers to cover drug costs for people on Medicare. But, they said, in places where no private insurers enter the market, the government itself should assume the financial risk and the responsibility for providing such coverage.

headline.main: In Policy Change, House Republicans Call for Government Guarantee of Drug Benefits

docs.abstract: House Republicans, after insisting for months that private insurance is only way to provide prescription drug benefits to elderly, hold federal government must be insurer of last resort to guarantee that drug coverage is available to all Medicare beneficiaries; says they will draft bill under which government will offer private insurers subsidies to cover drug costs for people on Medicare and provide coverage where no private insurers enter market; Rep Bill Thomas, who leads Republican efforts to write bill, comments; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-16 Leaders of Two Koreas Confer in Pyongyang Opening formalities at the first summit meeting between North and South Korea seemed surprisingly relaxed, exceeding the expectations of many people, including perhaps those of the principals themselves, Kim Jong Il of the North and Kim Dae Jung of the South. During a 27 minute-meeting, they discussed the need to establish a hotline, and talks today are expected to focus on issues that divide the two countries. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court's unanimous decision that patients cannot sue health maintenance organizations for giving their doctors financial incentives to hold down costs is a reasoned analysis of the state of federal law. But the decision also underscores the need for Congress to set standards for how the managed-care industry operates and to expand the rights of patients who have been harmed by managed-care decisions, including the denial of care. The case, Pegram v. Herdrich, has been watched with considerable interest because it deals with whether a for-profit managed-care plan violates its fiduciary duties to patients by rationing care. The plaintiff sued her H.M.O., a doctor-owned health plan, and her doctor under state law for medical malpractice and fraud when her appendix ruptured while she was made to wait for several days for an ultrasound test. She eventually won $35,000 in damages on the malpractice claim.
docs.abstract: Editorial holds Supreme Court ruling that patients cannot sue health maintenance organizations for giving doctors financial incentives to hold down costs underscores need for Congress to set standards for managed-care industry and expand rights of patients harmed by managed-care decisions

docs.lead_paragraph: THE Supreme Court blasted a hole in the courtroom assault on managed care this week, pleasing Wall Street, but outside experts and lawyers on both sides in dozens of lawsuits insisted yesterday that there were still plenty of issues left to fight over. In a unanimous opinion that was hailed by the industry, the court gave its blessing on Monday to a core practice of managed care insurers: the offering of financial incentives to physicians who limit costs by restricting care. The court rejected arguments that an Illinois health maintenance organization had violated a federal law in the case of Cynthia Herdrich, who said that her H.M.O. doctor delayed treatment for her appendicitis. The justices said her complaint belonged in state court where, in fact, she had won $35,000.

headline.main: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A favorable Supreme Court ruling lifts health care company stocks, but more lawsuits loom.

docs.abstract: Supreme Court's ruling that allows managed care insurers to offer financial incentives to doctors who limit costs by restricting care lifts health care company stocks; Supreme Court leaves open whether insurance companies can be punished under federal pension and health care law for failing to disclose to consumers that they use such inventives and other business methods that affect patient care (Market Place column) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Today's Supreme Court decision, rejecting a patient's lawsuit against a health maintenance organization, means that it is now up to Congress to decide whether patients gain new rights to sue H.M.O.'s for injuries they suffer at the hands of doctors and insurers. In his opinion for a unanimous court, Justice David H. Souter said Congress had ''a superior institutional competence'' in deciding how to hold H.M.O.'s accountable. Congress, he said, is the ''preferable forum'' for deciding such complex questions.

headline.main: Ruling Sends Call for Action To Congress and the States

docs.abstract: Unanimous decision by US Supreme Court rejecting patient's lawsuit against health maintenance organization for giving doctors incentives for cutting health costs, leaves it up to Congress to decide whether patients gain new rights to sue HMO's for injuries they suffer at hands of doctors and insurers; article examines different versions of patients' rights legislation pending in House and Senate (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court today spared managed health care from a potentially fatal legal attack, ruling unanimously that the financial incentives that health maintenance organizations give doctors to hold down costs do not make the H.M.O.'s liable to suit in federal court for violating a duty to put their patients first. ''No H.M.O. organization could survive without some incentive connecting physician reward with treatment rationing,'' Justice David H. Souter wrote for the court. Noting that Congress had given its blessing to this form of health care delivery, he said, ''The judiciary has no warrant to precipitate the upheaval that would follow'' if the essential structure of managed care was itself a source of legal liability.

headline.main: H.M.O.'s Win Crucial Ruling On Liability for Doctors' Acts

docs.abstract: US Supreme Court rules unanimously that financial incentives that health maintenance organizations give doctors to hold down costs do not make them liable to federal suits for violating duty to put patients first; dismisses suit by Cynthia Herdrich, whose appendix burst after health maintenance organization in Urbana, Ill, forced her to wait eight days for tests to diagnose abdominal pain; leaves such lawsuits in province of state courts while handing back to Congress issue of patients rights as matter of federal policy (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's ruling today that a patient cannot use the federal Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 to sue a health maintenance organization for giving doctors a financial incentive to cut treatment costs. Justice David H. Souter wrote the opinion for a unanimous court. The question in this case is whether treatment decisions made by a health maintenance organization, acting through its physician employees, are fiduciary acts within the meaning of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. . . . We hold that they are not.

headline.main: Excerpts From Court's Ruling on Suing H.M.O.'s

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK MANHATTAN: GRACIE MANSION RULING A federal judge in Manhattan ordered New York City yesterday to allow a group of protesters to sleep on the sidewalk across from Gracie Mansion, provided that they obey certain conditions. City lawyers had said the protesters would be violating the disorderly conduct law. Judge Kimba M. Wood of United States District Court ruled that the protesters, who object to proposed rent increases for rent-controlled apartments, would be exercising their First Amendment rights. But she said that they must not block the sidewalk. The demonstration is planned for Thursday night. John Sullivan (NYT)
